title: التَّنَازُعُ
description: Learn about التنازع, a grammatical phenomenon where two verbs compete to govern a single noun, and how Arabic resolves this conflict.

notes.title: What is التنازع?
content: التنازع is a grammatical phenomenon that occurs when two or more verbs (عاملان) precede a single noun (معمول واحد), and each verb seeks to govern that noun grammatically.
For example, in the sentence: قَامَ وَقَعَدَ زَيْدٌ (Zaid stood and sat), both قام and قعد are competing to make زيد their subject (فاعل).
This creates a 'conflict' that Arabic grammar must resolve by determining which verb takes the noun as its actual grammatical dependent.
keyPoints: التنازع requires at least two verbs (or verb-like elements)
Both verbs must be capable of governing the shared noun
The noun typically appears after both verbs
One verb will take the noun; the other requires a pronoun reference

examples.english: Muhammad came to me and I honored him
Ali loves me and I love him

notes.title: The Two Schools of Thought
content: The Basran grammarians (البصريون) prefer giving governance to the closer verb (الثاني/the second), because it is nearer to the noun and proximity strengthens the connection.
The Kufan grammarians (الكوفيون) prefer giving governance to the first verb (الأول), because it came first and has priority by precedence.
Both views are acceptable in Arabic, though the Basran view is more commonly followed in later grammatical tradition.
keyPoints: البصريون: The second (closer) verb governs the noun
الكوفيون: The first verb governs the noun
The non-governing verb needs a pronoun (ضمير) referring to the noun

examples.english: Zaid hit me and I hit him (Basran: second verb governs)
Zaid hit me and I hit him (Kufan: first verb governs)
I honored Khalid and he honored me
I taught and the teacher taught me

notes.title: Conditions for التنازع
content: For التنازع to occur properly, several conditions must be met. The verbs must be capable of taking the shared element as their grammatical dependent.
The shared element can be a subject (فاعل), object (مفعول به), or other governed element. Both verbs must require this element grammatically.
If one verb requires a subject and another requires an object, each may take what it needs, or one will govern and the other will have a pronoun.
keyPoints: Both verbs must be transitive or intransitive as needed
The shared noun must fit grammatically with both verbs
If verbs differ in transitivity, resolution becomes more complex
A pronoun (مستتر or متصل) compensates for the non-governing verb

examples.english: The student read and wrote the lesson
The friend visited me and I visited him
I helped my brother and he helped me

notes.title: Examples from Classical Arabic
content: التنازع appears in the Quran and classical Arabic poetry, demonstrating its natural occurrence in eloquent Arabic discourse.
The Quran contains examples where two verbs share a grammatical element, resolved elegantly through context and meaning.
Understanding التنازع helps in parsing complex classical Arabic sentences and appreciating the flexibility of Arabic syntax.
keyPoints: التنازع is found in the Quran and hadith
Classical poets used it for metrical and stylistic purposes
Understanding it is essential for advanced Arabic study

examples.english: Bring me, I will pour over it molten copper
Come, the Messenger of Allah will seek forgiveness for you
The guest came and went happily

exercises.promptEn: I visited the _____ yesterday and he visited me
My _____ helped me in the war and I helped him

exercises.prompt: I honored and respected the teacher
The student read and wrote the lesson

exercises.answer: conflict in governance (when two verbs compete for one noun)
